title: A historic house’s story can help it sell — but not always
text:
While many think a notable lineage increases a home’s value, historic structures also come with easements, higher insurance costs and complex structural issues. (Peter and Maria Hoey/for The Washington Post)

More than 200 years after George Washington delivered his farewell address to the nation, his onetime presence at a property remains a selling point.

“We always research every historic home to find out the story about who lived there or who visited there,” says Phyllis Patterson, a senior vice president with TTR Sotheby’s International Realty in Old Town Alexandria. “Any house that has anything to do with George Washington usually sells faster than other historic homes.”

Virginia is not the only place where a Washington connection affects sales.

“People came from all over the country to see a house that was for sale in the Germantown neighborhood in Philadelphia because George Washington spent the summer there one year,” says Louise D’Alessandro, an associate broker with Elfant Wissahickon Realtors in Philadelphia.

History buffs from around the country and globe may visit historic homes, but buyers are typically local, says D’Alessandro, at least in Philadelphia.

The history of a house will ultimately be most important and relevant to the person who buys the house, says Theresa Burt, an associate broker with Washington Fine Properties and Georgetown resident.

“When selling the house, an agent must be careful about the marketing,” Burt said. “The decision regarding to include the history of the house in pre-marketing depends upon the story — is it sensational? Salacious? Helpful or hurtful to the sale? What if a prominent political family lived in the home?”

When researching the history of one of her recent listings, Burt learned the home had been a saloon famous among sea captains and later a small hospital during the Civil War.

“Simply interesting, sad or perhaps too dramatic for the imagination of today’s buyer,” she said. “One needs to be sensitive to the story. We research the history of the house and provide it to potential buyers, if they are interested. There’s a difference between promoting the history and making it available upon request.”

Historic houses sometimes take longer to sell than more modern ones because old houses require more maintenance and can have preservation restrictions.

Determining a sale price for a historic home can be challenging, as comparable properties to use for comparisons may not exist.

“Lots of people see more value in older homes because of their architecture and history, but some people err on the side of caution because a historic designation can limit the work that homeowners can do or make it more expensive,” says Renee Peres, a real estate agent with Compass in Washington.

Stories about previous residents can entice potential buyers, but the architectural and historical details are what convert visitors to owners, says Leslie Brenowitz, a real estate agent also with Compass in the District.

“Buyers are looking for the features that you don’t see today, such as turrets and transoms and thick walls,” says Brenowitz. “They want to see the original fireplaces and millwork.”

Brenowitz and Peres are selling a single-family home in the LeDroit Park neighborhood of Northwest Washington, one of 50 remaining homes designed by architect James McGill between 1873 and 1883.

“The neighborhood is a historic district, which has attracted some out-of-state buyers, but we don’t know much about the previous owners of this house,” says Peres. “We’re finding that the more typical buyer of a historic home is someone who appreciates the architecture and knows they can’t afford to build something like this today.”

The buyer pool for older homes in Old Town Alexandria, says Patterson, is limited to people who want to own and preserve a historic landmark and have the means to do that.

“Buyers want a story, but they also want a house with a renovated kitchen and bathrooms,” says Patterson. “Along with the original floors, doors and fireplaces, they ideally want some green space accessible from an open kitchen and family room.”

If a home in Old Town has off-street parking, that can easily add $100,000 to the price, Patterson says.

“We market historic homes to people who buy antiques through Sotheby’s, to members of groups with an interest in history and internationally, too,” says Patterson.

Selling a historic house can be more complex because older homes can have more structural issues that must be disclosed to buyers, and they often come with easements and historic regulations that may affect what a buyer can do to the home.

“Homeowners usually want a historic designation for their house because [they think] it adds to the home’s value, but it also restricts them,” says Patterson.

Historic houses can be less valuable than a more modern home because of the constraints on remodeling and the expense of renovations, agents say. Historic houses often lack parking and are less likely to have the open floor plan preferred by today’s buyers.

Patterson says exterior renovations to houses in Old Town Alexandria must be reviewed by the Board of Architectural Review. Owners of homes within the historic district face more limitations.

“Historic homes need specialists and craftsmen with experience to work on them, and sometimes an engineer needs to be consulted to make sure that the home is structurally sound,” says Patterson.

Appraisers don’t factor in a property’s historic status when determining the valuation, says D’Alessandro.

“There’s a chance that a property with too many easements could appraise lower, but generally we price properties based on nearby homes in a comparable condition,” says D’Alessandro. “Just like any other house, a historic house that’s priced right will sell faster.”

In LeDroit Park’s historic district, homeowners must preserve the facade, street view and roof line of the homes, which means they can’t expand with a pop-up extension, says Brenowitz.

“The materials to restore the exterior also have to be consistent with the original house,” she says. “Sometimes that costs more, such as installing wood windows, but sometimes it can cost less. A concrete porch is less expensive than a brick porch, for example.”

Grants are available from nonprofit organizations and local governments to help homeowners preserve historic homes, says Peres.

Insurance costs for a historic home may be higher than average depending on the location, construction and materials of the property, says Patterson. Not every insurance company offers coverage for historic homes, so buyers need to investigate insurance costs before finalizing their purchase.

Purchasers of historic homes take on more than an ownership role: They are responsible for maintaining history. Before the National Trust for Historic Preservation sells its properties, buyers go through interviews about their intentions for it.

“Buying a home in a historic neighborhood or that has a historic designation from a local, state or national organization typically means you can’t alter the exterior,” says Peres. “When you do an interior renovation, it’s best to be thoughtful about the historic integrity of the home for future resale value. While a new kitchen and bathrooms are important, it’s also smart to be consistent with the rest of the house and to honor its history.”
description: While many think a notable lineage increases a home’s value, historic structures also come with easements, higher insurance costs and complex structural issues.
